channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Justice Department revokes Biden-era protections for reporters in leak investigations
item.description: In a new memo, Attorney General Pam Bondi said the DOJ will allow for subpoenas, court orders and search warrants to get information and testimony from journalists.
item.content:encoded:
In a new memo, Attorney General Pam Bondi said the DOJ will allow for subpoenas, court orders and search warrants to get information and testimony from journalists.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Ryan Lucas

item.title: Government says - for now - it will restore international students' status
item.description: International students had filed dozens of lawsuits after the government removed them from a database crucial for maintaining their legal status.
item.content:encoded:
International students had filed dozens of lawsuits after the government removed them from a database crucial for maintaining their legal status.

(Image credit: Nam Y. Huh)
item.dc:creator: Adrian Florido

item.title: A Jewish baking tradition rises in the age of Instagram
item.description: Shlissel challah is a special loaf baked the first sabbath after Passover. We trace the modern route by which the bread has spread beyond the ultra-orthodox world to everyday Jewish bakers.
item.content:encoded:
Shlissel challah is a special loaf baked the first sabbath after Passover. We trace the modern route by which the bread has spread beyond the ultra-orthodox world to everyday Jewish bakers.

(Image credit: Shprinzy Friedman)
item.dc:creator: Deena Prichep

item.title: New senior staff announced as White House looks to 'right the ship' at the Pentagon
item.description: The defense department has announced new senior level positions after recent firings and resignations. But with Pentagon head Pete Hegseth under fire for missteps, the way ahead is still unclear.
item.content:encoded:
The defense department has announced new senior level positions after recent firings and resignations. But with Pentagon head Pete Hegseth under fire for missteps, the way ahead is still unclear.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Tom Bowman

item.title: Luigi Mangione's case marks a shift in politics of the death penalty in the U.S.
item.description: Over the last half-century, the political leanings of the Supreme Court, Congress, and the presidency contributed to dramatically different approaches to the federal death penalty.
item.content:encoded:
Over the last half-century, the political leanings of the Supreme Court, Congress, and the presidency contributed to dramatically different approaches to the federal death penalty.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Kristin Wright

item.title: Where's Plumpy'Nut? A lifesaving food for malnourished kids is caught up in U.S. cuts
item.description: It's a "ready-to-use therapeutic food" that's had remarkable success in treating malnourished kids. The State Department says it's still available. Factories and field workers have a different view.
item.content:encoded:
It's a "ready-to-use therapeutic food" that's had remarkable success in treating malnourished kids. The State Department says it's still available. Factories and field workers have a different view.

(Image credit: Gabrielle Emanuel/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Jewel Bright

item.title: A New Mission for Syria's Famed White Helmets
item.description: During Syria's long civil war, the White Helmets were known for running into harms way, rescuing civilians from the aftermath of regime attacks. Now with the regime gone, the famed organization is finding a new mission with new challenges. We go to Damascus to see them in action.
item.content:encoded: During Syria's long civil war, the White Helmets were known for running into harms way, rescuing civilians from the aftermath of regime attacks. Now with the regime gone, the famed organization is finding a new mission with new challenges. We go to Damascus to see them in action.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Frayer

item.title: Fired, rehired, and fired again: Some federal workers find they're suddenly uninsured
item.description: Commerce Department employees caught up in a legal battle over their mass firings are now learning that their health care coverage was cut off weeks ago, even though they were paying their premiums.
item.content:encoded:
Commerce Department employees caught up in a legal battle over their mass firings are now learning that their health care coverage was cut off weeks ago, even though they were paying their premiums.

(Image credit: Andrea Hsu)
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hsu

item.title: What it's like in the church Pope Francis chose as his final resting place
item.description: Pope Francis will be buried in St. Mary Major church, not Saint Peter's Basilica, in a break with tradition.
item.content:encoded:
Pope Francis will be buried in St. Mary Major church, not Saint Peter's Basilica, in a break with tradition.

(Image credit: Vatican)
item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock

item.title: Angie Murimirwa: From hiding in the bathroom to Time's most influential people list
item.description: A kid whose parents couldn't afford school fees is now an "icon" on Time magazine's 2025 list — recognizing her work as CEO of Camfed, a charity that gives millions of girls a chance for an education.
item.content:encoded:
A kid whose parents couldn't afford school fees is now an "icon" on Time magazine's 2025 list — recognizing her work as CEO of Camfed, a charity that gives millions of girls a chance for an education.

(Image credit: Kevin Mazur)
item.dc:creator: Marc Silver
